wjim1269

Paul Harvey's comment on Columbine High shootings:
 
 How can we blame it all on guns? For the life of me, I can't understand what could have gone wrong in Littleton, CO. If only the parents had kept their children away from the guns, we wouldn't have had such a tragedy. Yeah, it must have been the guns.
 
 It couldn't have been because half our children are being raised in broken homes.
 
 It couldn't have been because our children get to spend an average of 30 seconds in meaningful conversation with their parents each day. After all, we give our children quality time.
 
 It couldn't have been because we treat our children as pets and our pets as children.
 
 It couldn't have been because we place our children in day care centers where they learn their socialization skills among their peers under the law of the jungle while employees who have no vested interest in the children look on and make sure that no blood is spilled.
 
 It couldn't have been because we allow our children to watch, on the average, seven hours of television a day filled with the glorification of sex and violence that isn't fit for even adult consumption.
 
 It couldn't have been because we allow our children to enter into virtual worlds in which, to win the game, one must kill as many opponents as possible in the most sadistic way possible.
 
 It couldn't have been because we have sterilized and contracepted our families down to sizes so small that the children we do have are so spoiled with material things that they come to equate the receiving of the material with love.
 
 It couldn't have been because our children, who historically have been seen as a blessing from God, are now being viewed as either a mistake created when contraception fails or inconveniences that parents try to raise in their spare time.
 
 It couldn't have been because we give two-year prison sentences to teenagers who kill their newborns.
 
 It couldn't have been because our school systems teach he children that they are nothing but glorified apes who have
 evolutionized out of some primordial soup of mud by teaching evolution as fact and by handing out condoms as if they were candy.
 
 It couldn't have been because we teach our children that there are no laws of morality that transcend us, that everything is relative and that actions don't have consequences. What the heck, the president gets away with it.
 
 Nah, it couldn't have been any of these. It must have been the guns.
 
 - Paul Harvey

 Does not even mention guns.

 So? There are other articles and books that do. Is your link the ultimate authority on the cause of crime?
wjim1269

Simply not true.
 
 
 Then what is your plan to get rid of all of the other issues. Maybe if we got rid of them, we wouldn't have to worry about debating gun control?
kelvin90701

Originally posted by wjim1269 
 Then what is your plan to get rid of all of the other issues. Maybe if we got rid of them, we wouldn't have to worry about debating gun control? 
 
 
 Sir you are absolutely right.
 
 I do not pretend to have the answer to establish a society that will make every citizen not want to commit a violet crime.
 
 I do not buy into ant-gunner proposal that we will achive that protected society by banning guns.
 
 I turn around the question to anti-guners. Why the focus on guns and the lack of focus on:
 
 poverty
 education
 family stability
 media violence
 hoplessness?
 
 All of which are root causes of gun crime.
Crim

Let's just knock off a couple of these which are garbage.
 
 
It couldn't have been because we allow our children to watch, on the average, seven hours of television a day filled with the glorification of sex and violence that isn't fit for even adult consumption.
 
 
It couldn't have been because we allow our children to enter into virtual worlds in which, to win the game, one must kill as many opponents as possible in the most sadistic way possible.
 
 
 There's no causality between watching/playing violent media and performing violent acts. People who are aggressive will buy entertainment which suits them. The entertainment itself isn't causing them to be aggressive. For many, the opposite is true. Like sports, violent video games can be an outlet for aggression and anger.
 
 
It couldn't have been because our school systems teach he children that they are nothing but glorified apes who have evolutionized out of some primordial soup of mud by teaching evolution as fact 
 
 
 This is clearly the worst one. Mr. Harvey shows his ignorance and dislike of science.
 
 
Nah, it couldn't have been any of these. It must have been the guns.
 
 
 How about it was the PEOPLE WHO COMMITTED THE ACT?
kelvin90701

Originally posted by Crim 
 Let's just knock off a couple of these which are garbage.
 
 
 There's no causality between watching/playing violent media and performing violent acts. People who are aggressive will buy entertainment which suits them. The entertainment itself isn't causing them to be aggressive. For many, the opposite is true. Like sports, violent video games can be an outlet for aggression and anger.
 
 How about it was the PEOPLE WHO COMMITTED THE ACT? 
 
 
 Your only partly right. Personal responsibility has a lot to do with the act. The teenagers who committed the act and the parents who failed to supervise thier teenagers.
 
 Media violence also has a lot to do with it, there is a casuality:
 
 http://www.apa.org/pubinfo/violence.html
 
 "It is also true that while guns facilitate the act of killing, guns do not create the mindset for the action."
 
 http://www.innerself.com/Parenting/movies.htm
 
 To aviod laying all the blame on the perps, in their defense they are also victims of harasment(form of intimidation and violence). Blame and responsibility are two different things. Lots of people are to share in the blame (Hollywood, violent games, bullies, school counselors, etc) , but only the perps and thier parents were responsible.
wjim1269

Let's just knock off a couple of these which are garbage.

 
 You can try to knock off as many as you like, but you won't be able to knock off the point, which is that there are factors other than guns that need to be dealt with.
 
 The three issues you bring up are very good points, and I agree with you to some extent on all three of them.
 
 
There's no causality between watching/playing violent media and performing violent acts. People who are aggressive will buy entertainment which suits them. The entertainment itself isn't causing them to be aggressive. For many, the opposite is true. Like sports, violent video games can be an outlet for aggression and anger.

 
 I agree with you on this one. There is no connection between using the games and committing violent acts. However, as you stated already, "People who are aggressive will buy entertainment which suits them." Regardless of what games they play, people who are agressive will probably tend to be more violent.
 
 
This is clearly the worst one. Mr. Harvey shows his ignorance and dislike of science.

 
 So what if he dislikes science? If he believes something else, he has the right to believe that way. My problem here is that he shows more closed-mindedness to the viewpoints of others.
 
 
How about it was the PEOPLE WHO COMMITTED THE ACT?

 
 Exactly. And what do guns have to do with that? Absolutely nothing.
kelvin90701

[QUOTE=wjim1269]
 
 
 I agree with you on this one. There is no connection between using the games and committing violent acts. QUOTE]
 
 
 Hmmm. Committing a specific act, No. Influencing individuals and groups of young individuals to become more violent, yes.
 
 "Researchers have raised concerns about the potential link between playing violent video games and subsequent aggressive behavior. A number of studies have shown such effects, with younger children being particularly susceptible to influence. 9 "
 
 http://www.mediascope.org/pubs/ibriefs/vgv.htm
wjim1269

The only problem I have with those studies is that they lack an important control group. (I will get to that control group in a second.) I agree that there is a connection between those who play violent video games and those who commit crimes, but does one cause the other? It is certainly within the realm of possibilities, but that does not necessarily have to be the case. As Crim mentioned, "People who are aggressive will buy entertainment which suits them." Is the increase in crimes vs. the population due to the video games, or is it simply because the people who play those games are more agressive (and in that case, would probably have committed those crimes anyway)?
 
 The control group that is lacking is a group of people who would play the video games, but do not. It will be almost impossible to assemble a group of these people because first of all, we can't tell kids what games they can or cannot play; secondly, people's definition of "violent" could be different; and last, we would have no way to prove that the person did not play those games.
Crim

The studies showing a link between violent videogames and aggression are weak at best. They come up with results like the study group playing a loud noise for 0.16 seconds longer than the control group. WOW, THEY WENT PSYCHO. 
 
 Despite videogame sales GROWING to almost 20 billion dollars, violent crime among minors has been going DOWN.
kelvin90701

The only problem I have with those studies is that they lack an important control group. (I will get to that control group in a second.) I agree that there is a connection between those who play violent video games and those who commit crimes, but does one cause the other? It is certainly within the realm of possibilities, but that does not necessarily have to be the case. As Crim mentioned, "People who are aggressive will buy entertainment which suits them." Is the increase in crimes vs. the population due to the video games, or is it simply because the people who play those games are more agressive (and in that case, would probably have committed those crimes anyway)?
 
 The control group that is lacking is a group of people who would play the video games, but do not. It will be almost impossible to assemble a group of these people because first of all, we can't tell kids what games they can or cannot play; secondly, people's definition of "violent" could be different; and last, we would have no way to prove that the person did not play those games.

 
 You are both making valid critical questions that I can not answer. The link is a report on a study, not the study itselft. 
 
 You are also making blanket statments such as: "The control group that is lacking is a group of people who would play the video games." 
 
 You don't know. 
 
 "it may be reasonably inferred from the more than 1,000 reports and studies on television violence that video game violence "
 
 Have you had time to review the 1,000 reports? To see what kind of protcall has been followed for the study or experiment? The link is also making similiar unsupported suppositions such as: "In addition, the increasing realism might encourage greater identification with characters and more imitation of the behaviors of video game models. "
 
 I agree that this particular link/report is incomplete. There has been enough similiar studies for me to conclude that something is happening with people and violent entertainment.
wjim1269

You are also making blanket statments such as: "The control group that is lacking is a group of people who would play the video games." 
 
 You don't know. 

 
 You're right. I don't know. However, I know that it would be almost impossible to assemble a control group for a study like that. Would it be possible? Yes. But it is so close to impossible that I doubt it would happen. Also, I have looked at some of the studies that have been done, and none of them have involved a control group like that. The control groups in the ones I have looked at were either the population or a group of kids who play non-violent games.
 
 
I agree that this particular link/report is incomplete. There has been enough similiar studies for me to conclude that something is happening with people and violent entertainment.

 
 I disagree to some extent. I play paintball quite often (basically simulating war, for proof of its violence), and I would never think about taking a gun and shooting someone.
 
 I'm sure there are some people who have played violent games to the point where the games have affected their minds. Do they affect some? Yes. Do they affect everyone in the same way? No. Do they affect the majority? That is what I am debating. Despite the studies that point in the direction of yes, I don't think we can tell.
